hints_html:
To find the nullspace \(N(\hat A)\), look for vectors x such that

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = \hat A x = U\hat \Sigma V^*x\end{aligned}\]

Since U is unitary, the only way that \(U\hat \Sigma V^*x = 0\) is that \(\hat \Sigma V^*x = 0\). Find the nullspace of \(\hat \Sigma\) and relate the result to \(V^* x\). Solve for x.

To calculate \(\|\hat A -A\|\) use that \(\hat A - A = U\hat \Sigma V^* - U \Sigma V^* = U(\hat \Sigma -\Sigma)V^*\).

question: 6 (f)
sols_html:
Let’s start by calculating the nullspace of \(\hat A\), that is, we are looking for vectors x such that

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = \hat A x = U\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}V^* x = U\hat \Sigma V^*x\end{aligned}\]

Since U is unitary, Uy = 0 implies y = 0. Hence, for \(\hat A x = 0\) is only possible if and only if \(\hat \Sigma V^* x = 0.\) Let’s abbreviate \(\displaystyle V^*x = z\). Then, in order to find the nullspace of \(\hat A\) we are looking for vectors z such that \(\hat \Sigma z = 0.\) This equation can quickly be solved

\[\begin{aligned} z = \begin{bmatrix}0 \\ 0 \\ t\end{bmatrix} = te_3,\end{aligned}\]

for any real value of t. Since \(\displaystyle z = V^* x\) we solve for x and find

\[\begin{aligned} x = (V^*)^{-1}z = Vz = tVe_3 = t\begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt 6 \\ -1/\sqrt 6 \\ -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, \(N(\hat A) = t\begin{bmatrix} 2/\sqrt 6 \\ -1/\sqrt 6 \\ -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix}\)

Next, observe that

\[\begin{aligned} \hat{A}-A = U \hat \Sigma V^{*}-U\Sigma V^{*} = U(\hat \Sigma-\Sigma )V^{*}\end{aligned}\]

Again following the logic of part (c) it holds that

\[\begin{aligned} \|\hat A\| = \|\hat \Sigma-\Sigma\| = \left\|\begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & -1/2 \end{bmatrix}\right\| = 1/2\end{aligned}\]

statement_html:
Suppose that A is a matrix with singular value decomposition \(A = U\Sigma V^*\) where

\[\begin{aligned} U &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 2 & 1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \\ \Sigma &= \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix} \\ V &= \begin{bmatrix} 1/\sqrt 3 & 0 & 2/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & 1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \\ 1/\sqrt 3 & -1/\sqrt 2 & -1/\sqrt 6 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

(f) Let

\[\begin{aligned} \hat A = U \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 0 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} V^*\end{aligned}\]

where U and V are the matrices given above. Then \(\hat A\) is a matrix with a non-trivial null space. What is a basis for \(N(\hat A)\)? What is the norm \(\|\hat A - A\|\)?
